body:
Build fails when using Android studio *Run* button but works using `flutter run` from terminal. 

Using Ubuntu, using snaps for both Android studio and Flutter

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Android studio `sudo snap install android-studio --classic`
2. Install flutter `sudo snap install flutter --classic`
3. Install Linux dependencies `sudo apt-get install clang cmake ninja-build pkg-config libgtk-3-dev`
4. Set flutter up `flutter channel dev &&  flutter upgrade && flutter config --enable-linux-desktop`
5. Create and run a dummy flutter project `flutter create counter && cd counter && flutter run -d linux`
6. Open Android studio
7. Install dart and flutter plugins
8. Restart Android studio
9. Open the _counter_ project just created
10. On the top select *Linux* as device
11. Click on `main.dart` and edit configuration to add `--verbose` to _Additional Arguments_
12. Click run

comment_data.body:
## Workaround
Create a shell script in the main folder of the application named `flutter_run.sh`
and paste this as content:
```sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash
flutter run $@
```

Then from the configuration editor, add a new configuration of type *Shell Script*. Set the path to the file just created. Optionally you can add the arguments you would pass to flutter doctor (e.g. `--verbose`) in the *Script options*.

With this it works with the convenience of just pushing a button.

Thanks for the report. Unfortunately, I don't have Linux so I can't help much.

I see a couple differences in the command executed following `Launching lib/main.dart on Linux in debug mode...`
- The one launched from the IDE includes `-Dflutter.inspector.structuredErrors=true`
- The one from the command line has `--filesystem-scheme org-dartlang-root`

Which makes me wonder if the command line version would work if you include the `--machine` option. The IDE also adds the `--start-paused` option. If you have a chance could you try running `flutter run --machine --verbose` from the command line? Another thing to try would be adding `--filesystem-scheme org-dartlang-root` to the run config in the IDE.

I notice your Linux toolchain has different versions of most items. Why would that be? Also, ninja says `ninja: warning: bad deps log signature or version; starting over` running from the command line (which is the older version) but not from the IDE. That happens almost immediately after it starts. I'm not familiar with ninja so I don't know if that is significant.

> I notice your Linux toolchain has different versions of most items. Why would that be?

Honestly I'm not sure about the multiple toolchain thing. It might be because of the snaps environment, but I'm not sure at all. I really think that when run from the IDE somehow the wrong toolchain is selected, but I'm not sure what component is to blame..

> Also, ninja says ninja: warning: bad deps log signature or version; starting over running from the command line (which is the older version) but not from the IDE. That happens almost immediately after it starts. I'm not familiar with ninja so I don't know if that is significant.

I'm not familiar with it either, however it happens both from command line or IDE, so I think it's unlikely to be the cause of the issue.
@csells , @kenvandine can you have a look at this issue to see if it might be related to snaps?
Thanks @fcole90 for the follow-up. We'll need to find someone with Linux to investigate. Sorry I can't do more.
No worries, I tagged Chris and Ken for this reason :wink:
@MarcusTomlinson can you please take a look at this?

I think this is related to this issue: https://github.com/kenvandine/flutter-snap/issues/8.

To summarize what I think is going on:
- android studio is running the `flutter` command from the snap installed flutter sdk - `$HOME/snap/flutter/common/flutter/bin/flutter`
- that does not run w/ any of the necessary env. variables to set up the paths for locating the native tooling necessary to build flutter desktop apps
- the snap also installs a separate shell script, `/snap/flutter/current/flutter.sh`
- that does do things like set up the native tool paths: https://github.com/kenvandine/flutter-snap/blob/master/env.sh

So, the flutter sdk from the snap won't be able to build flutter desktop apps; tools instead have to call the /snap/flutter/current/flutter.sh script, which sets up the path and calls `flutter` from the sdk.

I think what would be useful here is to have some way for the flutter sdk installed via snap to be configured w/ knowledge of the necessary env. vars / paths - for tools and users to be able to call the `<flutter-sdk>/bin/flutter` sdk entrypoint. I'll make a comment to that effect on the flutter-snap repo issue.
